citation.article-title: Clostridium cylindrosporum, ex Barker and Beck 1972 nom. rev.

p.s: Description of Clostridium cylindrosporum (ex Barker and Beck 1942) sp. nov., nom. rev.
Clostridium cylindrosporum (cy.lin.dro.spo'rum. Gr.n. kylindros a cylinder; Gr.n. sporos a seed; N.L. adj. cylindrosporum cylinder spored)
Straight rods with an average length of 3.3 μm and an average diameter of 0.8 μm.
Motile by means of peritrichous flagella.
Colonies on solid medium unpigmented, flat, circular, and up to 2 mm in diameter.
Spore form cylindrical to oval, with a terminal to subterminal location.
Only actively growing cultures stain gram positive.
The pH optimum changes slightly with different substrates and ranges between pH 6.7 and 8.5.
Highest growth rates are observed at temperatures of 40 to 45°C; some growth occurs at 19°C.
Strictly anaerobic.
No growth occurs with a variety of carbohydrates, amino acids, aromatic compounds, organic acids (for a list see references 8 and 10), Milk medium, or chopped meat medium.
Only uric acid, xanthine, guanine, 6,8-dihydroxypurine, and hypoxanthine are used as carbon and energy sources.
A suitable medium has been described by Diirre et al. (8).
Glycine is fermented in combination with small amounts of uric acid or some other purines, whereas no degradation by growing cells occurs without the addition of a purine.
Marginal growth is observed with 4-aminoimidazole-5-carboxamide.
Some strains require thiamine and biotin for growth.
Selenite is an essential microdutrient.
Fermentation products from purines are acetate, formate, carbon dioxide, and ammonia; glycine is sometimes detectable in trace amounts (depending on the medium).
Acetoin, butanediol, butyrate, caproate, diacetyl, gas, indole, and sulfide are not produced.
Nitrate is not reduced.
Esculin, gelatin, and starch are not hydrolyzed.
Catalase, lecithinase, and urease activities are not detected.
Lipase is formed by a few strains.
No hemolysis of bovine erythrocytes occurs.
Growth occurs but is inhibited by the presence of 2% bile extract.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA is 27.2 to 30.4 mol% (thermal denaturation method).
Habitat: various strains have been isolated from different soils and from chicken intestines.
The description of the type strain is identical to that of the species; only thiamine and biotin are required vitamins.
Growth is optimal at pH 7.5 to 8.0.
Strain HC-1 of Barker and Beck (3) is the type strain and has been deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen as strain DSM 605 (= ATCC 7905) (guanine-plus-cytosine content, 27.9 mol%) .
